There seems to be no mention of the fact that excessive drinkers often lie about their consumption, to their doctors, their loved ones, and to themselves.  So, how do researchers get reliable information?  People are drinking a lot more than this article suggests.  (Yes, I used to be one of them.)

Your professional experience with women who have one drink a day plus a bonus is that they can't stop?  That they're dependent?  That doesn't pass the straight face test.  I don't HAVE to have a drink in the evening, but I often do.  I am not getting drunk and alcohol doesn't interfere with my functioning or life.  I find it hard to believe that my drinking is in anyway excessive, particularly since their are health benefits to light alcohol use.

Of course, you can drink as much as you want.  If you start feeling guilty, or deprived, then you'll have to start questioning yourself.  It generally takes a few years of abuse for the drinker to begin to realize that there may be a problem,  Beware of the statement, "I can stop any time I want to--I just don't want to."  But be aware, "health benefits" are not a good reason to drink.

I would have to see the survey questions asked to evaluate how the researchers decided these people were not dependent on alcohol. Self-reported responses by what they call "excessive drinkers" may not be reliable answers.

I have trouble believing the conclusion that nine out of 10 are not dependent or what's called "addicted" to alcohol. I also have trouble believing that their behavior can often change with "prompting" or that excessive drinking is "an easier problem to solve than previously believed".

My professional experience with people who drink that much is very different.

The notion that Democrats "lost" the election is peculiar and misguided. There was no national election or referendum on the ballot. Instead, there was a collection of Congressional races which, a priori, disfavored Democrats because of historical regional voting patterns. That situation will be dramatically reversed in 2016 Congressional races, and you will see a reversal of the party's fortunes in large part because of the simple geography of the races being contested. Beyond that fact, midterm elections nearly always disfavor the party holding the presidency.

So there was nothing at all unexpected about the outcome of the recent election, which had very little to do with the actual policies of the respective parties. You can simply look at each party's approval ratings for corroboration of that interpretation: Congressional Democrats consistently have higher favorability as a whole than Congressional Republicans, and the President has higher favorability than Congress.

And besides, since when did losing elections ever chasten Republicans or persuade them to heed the will of the American people?

comments.commentBody:
In response to "Jackie", yes, the factors you point out are generally correct. When I was in my high school years, we lived in Reading, Pa., a city which had a daily German language newspaper for decades. Of course, assimilation happens most comfortably with children, not adults. If it is easier to stick to the "old ways", more people might do it, rejecting much of what we consider important about our country.

What I was pointing out above, in shortened form, is that what has traditionally happened with immigrants to America might not be so routine any more. We can't rely on the past as a complete guide to the future. Our national belief in the law and the written Constitution, along with democratic principles not in use everywhere, are very important. So, too, is the fact that one can travel from coast to coast and not feel like a stranger.

The power of blending in for immigrants is very strong in this country. Most come here and want to be part of it in every way. Yet there are other forces at work. It is my assertion that too many immigrants too quickly, along with other factors, could create serious problems in the future.

There is also an undercurrent now that the descendents of European immigrants don't really have a right to be here themselves. I have seen signs at protests calling the majority population of America "invader Americans". Labeling American Indians as "native Americans", for example, downgrades the rest of us born here.

Things have really changed since the 1930s and those changes are part of what makes this whole issue very complex.

Ease of travel: we have jet planes now. The world, at least the portion with enough money to buy a one way ticket, can be at our doorstep within 24 hours. This speed of travel can mean that, once legal, people can fly frequently "back home", slowing, confusing assimilation.

Communications: people can come to America now and emotionally stay residents of the nations that gave them birth. They can be half way Americans and they can pass those attitudes down to their children. International television channels from nation's around the world, huge cultural anchors, are available on satellite and cable systems nationwide.

Yes, we can take immigrants and, yes, we need them. A lot of Americans seem to be losing the work ethic and also missing open business opportunities. (Thousands of small motels are now owned&operated by people from India. They found the key that Americans ignored.) Immigrants do bring new energy because they are more eager for what America offers and are willing to work hard, make sacrifices.

BUT, we can't take everyone. We can't let millions come and undermine the process by sheer numbers. When there is a process toward legalization, where do you put the STOP sign? We don't want to become a nation of differing languages and cultures where people don't know and fear each other, like many other nations. In all things, balance.

Doug Terry

On the other hand, if they fight the President's common sense proposal, they are going to lose the hispanic vote for a generation at least.

President Obama's initiative is going to go a long way towards opening our borders to tens of millions of poorly educated and low-skill immigrants. Why is there is so much support for this trend within America's financial and cultural elite?

First, because wealthy and powerful employers want to save costs and gain the upper hand for hiring all kinds of low-skilled but basic positions --assembly, clean-up & disposal, construction, child-care, etc.

Second, because there exists a genuine feeling of injustice and compassion for the millions of impoverished and exploited proletarians who crave a more decent and prosperous life for themselves and their children in "El Norte."

There are other reasons, of course --for instance, increasing the regional power of various ethnic, linguistic, religious and political communities, expanding the base of the Democratic Party, etc. -- but surely such reasons are unworthy of serious consideration.

Regarding the first rationale: Does it make sense for middle-class and blue-collar Americans to tolerate an inflow of low-level foreign workers during a period of intractable unemployment?

Regarding the second, why should a nation that is beginning to suffer from over-population open up its borders, even in the name of compassion, when there is a land immediately to the north, of comparable size and natural wealth, but with less than one tenth the population? Can't we arrange to transfer our illegals to Canada?
